Posts.Content: After extensive radiation of a prostate fossa-derived tumor surrounding my bladder (Dec/Jan 2012), my latest PSA reading was (to me at least) alarmingly high. I asked for a bone scan (last bone scan, six months previously, was clear). Results: Riddled with bone mets. Two weeks before, when I went in for my bone scan, I had had pain in my ribs when I moved, and I was thinking I strained my muscles somehow, and just relaxed for two weeks to "heal". Didn't work. Now I know why. I have these strong "ache" pains, sometimes when I move, sometimes it just up and slaps me when I am NOT moving. I can hardly wipe my _$$ without excruciating pain. I'm seeing my oncologist this Thursday for strategizing, and am ASSUMING chemo is next. Though I have been "Provenged", either it didn't take, or my aggressive Gleason 9 cancer is running away faster than the Provenge can keep up. What is YOUR experience with bone mets?
Posts.Signature: T-3, Gleason 9+ RRP 2-26-07 Was using Lupron HDT-- Successful for four years, Not working anymore! Fast-rising PSA 6/11 Provenge started 8/11 PCa invasion of bladder 9/11 Fossa lesion discovered 11/11 IMRT/IGRT 80 grays 12/11 Bone mets discovered 3/12 Provenge declared a "bust" Taxotere infusions started 4/12 PSA Coming Down PSA Going Back Up!! Taxotere declared a "bust" Zytiga, here we come! BAAD SE's on Zytiga, PSA quintupled! Now on Xtandi and Samarium 153
Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: DebbieMH--Thanks for the moral support. I know that everyone here is "concerned" with everyone else in the "club" and wishes the best. *ANY* success story fuels optimism but we are dealing with a wily "beast" here that has managed to out-fox the medical establishment even in these amazing modern times. Good vibes to us all! FWIW, the pain from the bone mets seems to have stabilized and even "retreated" a bit. Vicodin, Ibuprofen, and Percoset help with the pain, but I always abstain from pain-killer drugs the first few hours of the day to assess "the state of the pain". I truly believe I *AM* getting better, not just pollyanna wishfulness! Presumably the Zometa (bone-builder) has started to repair cancer-damaged bone material whilst the Taxotere disrupts cell functioning/repair/replacement and the cancer is temporarily stymied, all leading to reduced trauma on my bones (thus some diminution in pain). I really feel such a "pansy", as nearly ANY physical labor is eschewed (so I don't wrench my back unknowingly, as I have done a few times in the last months), but I truly think my situation is IMPROVED over the last two weeks.

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Update: I am now on Taxotere (3-week infusion), plus some other "helper" drugs. I have had so many needle-pricks, blood draws, and infusions that "they" are having a hard time finding useful veins (at least in my arms--where do they go from there--legs?). >SequoiaR, how fast is your PSA doubling? What is it currently?< Last month I had a PSA test to see how the extensive 80 Grays of radiation beat down the cancer. My pre-radiation PSA was 7.8; post-radiation was "5". Hmmm. I was suspicious that the number should have been MUCH lower. I am told that sometimes it took months for the radiation to work its magic, so I had another date with PSA scheduled for May. Then I went bold and ASKED for a bone scan. It was granted. That was BEFORE I had excruciating pain in my chest, spine and ribs (creeping up on me the past month--but truthfuly I had a "sore spot" by my sternum that didn't heal in two months). Bone scan results only last June showed NO bone mets. This scan showed me RIDDLED with bone mets, in all the places that ached. The latest PSA test came back--"greater than 20". OMG. That's at least FOUR times last month's reading!! So maybe my "doubling rate" is two weeks???? I was in the lowest, darkest region of my mind a few days before the Taxotere infusion, knowing I was truly "dying" with a close "expiriation date". I was thinking all my efforts in my little orchard, that were just now bearing miniature, growing fruit, would not be eaten by me this summer. I had done my last this-or-that, etc., and would leave a "widow" to fend for herself. Such mental agony. Now I'm in "pain management" with Vicodin (Dr. said I could have stronger stuff). But the pain seems to have stabilized and partially retreated with the Taxotere cocktail infusion (only 2 days ago!). I had the characteristic astringent tongue (like sucking on an un-ripe persimmon), tingles in the fingers and toes, and flushed face characteristic of Taxotere side-effects. UNLIKE "Provenge" (which I now think did NOT take in me--NO evidence of it retarding the cancer since August infusions) which has no real side effects I could feel, at least this Taxotere impresses me with ACTION I can FEEL!

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Sheesh! I am in IMMENSE pain in the ribs from time to time. My oncologist suggested I not play golf or other "strenuous activities" for fear of exacerbating the bone mets. Well....I thought I was "being careful" when I hauled a trash can up a flight of stairs. No problem then, but a few hours later my ribs just SCREAMED at me! The back muscles were "spasming" and I guess pulling on the weakened bones or something. Anyway, I had planned a road trip to see a good friend and had to cancel. NO WAY I could drive! So I'm hoping some rest and relaxation will "cure" this and get me back to merely dull ache. I may have to acquire some STRONG anti-pain pills as well. ;-(

Posts.Content: The Lupron *MAY* last a little longer than the three months "advertized", but why take a chance and let up when a regular schedule will keep it in your system supressing the growth of your cancer? I was on 6-mo Eligard shots for awhile, but I found that something went wrong and the Eligard quit working prematurely. My PSA and T-levels *SHOT* back up, and now "we" were "behind" the curve again. PC is mean stuff. Step on its neck and don't let up for a second lest you regret it!

I really feel such a "pansy", as nearly ANY physical labor is eschewed (so I don't wrench my back unknowingly, as I have done a few times in the last months), but I truly think my situation is IMPROVED over the last two weeks.

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: After extensive radiation of a prostate fossa-derived tumor surrounding my bladder (Dec/Jan 2012), my latest PSA reading was (to me at least) alarmingly high. I asked for a bone scan (last bone scan, six months previously, was clear). Results: Riddled with bone mets. Two weeks before, when I went in for my bone scan, I had had pain in my ribs when I moved, and I was thinking I strained my muscles somehow, and just relaxed for two weeks to "heal". Didn't work. Now I know why. I have these strong "ache" pains, sometimes when I move, sometimes it just up and slaps me when I am NOT moving. I can hardly wipe my _$$ without excruciating pain. I'm seeing my oncologist this Thursday for strategizing, and am ASSUMING chemo is next. Though I have been "Provenged", either it didn't take, or my aggressive Gleason 9 cancer is running away faster than the Provenge can keep up. What is YOUR experience with bone mets?

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Sheesh! I am in IMMENSE pain in the ribs from time to time. My oncologist suggested I not play golf or other "strenuous activities" for fear of exacerbating the bone mets. Well....I thought I was "being careful" when I hauled a trash can up a flight of stairs. No problem then, but a few hours later my ribs just SCREAMED at me! The back muscles were "spasming" and I guess pulling on the weakened bones or something. Anyway, I had planned a road trip to see a good friend and had to cancel. NO WAY I could drive! So I'm hoping some rest and relaxation will "cure" this and get me back to merely dull ache. I may have to acquire some STRONG anti-pain pills as well. ;-(

Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: Update: I am now on Taxotere (3-week infusion), plus some other "helper" drugs. I have had so many needle-pricks, blood draws, and infusions that "they" are having a hard time finding useful veins (at least in my arms--where do they go from there--legs?). >SequoiaR, how fast is your PSA doubling? What is it currently?< Last month I had a PSA test to see how the extensive 80 Grays of radiation beat down the cancer. My pre-radiation PSA was 7.8; post-radiation was "5". Hmmm. I was suspicious that the number should have been MUCH lower. I am told that sometimes it took months for the radiation to work its magic, so I had another date with PSA scheduled for May. Then I went bold and ASKED for a bone scan. It was granted. That was BEFORE I had excruciating pain in my chest, spine and ribs (creeping up on me the past month--but truthfuly I had a "sore spot" by my sternum that didn't heal in two months). Bone scan results only last June showed NO bone mets. This scan showed me RIDDLED with bone mets, in all the places that ached. The latest PSA test came back--"greater than 20". OMG. That's at least FOUR times last month's reading!! So maybe my "doubling rate" is two weeks???? I was in the lowest, darkest region of my mind a few days before the Taxotere infusion, knowing I was truly "dying" with a close "expiriation date". I was thinking all my efforts in my little orchard, that were just now bearing miniature, growing fruit, would not be eaten by me this summer. I had done my last this-or-that, etc., and would leave a "widow" to fend for herself. Such mental agony. Now I'm in "pain management" with Vicodin (Dr. said I could have stronger stuff). But the pain seems to have stabilized and partially retreated with the Taxotere cocktail infusion (only 2 days ago!). I had the characteristic astringent tongue (like sucking on an un-ripe persimmon), tingles in the fingers and toes, and flushed face characteristic of Taxotere side-effects. UNLIKE "Provenge" (which I now think did NOT take in me--NO evidence of it retarding the cancer since August infusions) which has no real side effects I could feel, at least this Taxotere impresses me with ACTION I can FEEL!

Posts.Content: I have decided against "Xtandi" and opted for "Zytiga" as my next, post-chemo choice of treatment. The "prostate guy" in my oncologist's group has several patients on "Xtandi" (formerly MDV3100) and they either ARE bed-ridden, or nearly so (from the extremely fatiguing side-effects of Xtandi, apparently). Zytiga patients are not so affected. I initially "chose" Xtandi as it did NOT require prednisone like Zytiga does. If they both did about the same thing, I would have rather NOT had cortizone in there, too. I pick up my Zytiga today, hopefully! (ps--it's my 64th birthday, too!)

Posts.Title: Back pain

Posts.Content: With prostate cancer, there are almost no outward "signs" of something wrong. But detecting it early can ward off many unpleasant effects of late-stage pc. There are SO MANY variables I wouldn't offer any "advice" other than if surgery is needed, any unpleasant side effects are preferable. I had removal surgery and my "nerves" and such NEEDED to be excized, so I live with zero sex life, but it is a small price to pay for additional years of loving living. I am fully continent, though---no pads. You need to spend some time researching, asking questions and having your oncologist/urologist explain options and side effects. All of us here have had to cope with "issues" relating to JUST what you are going through. You will reach a type of "peace" eventually. We here all know the scariness and uncertainty of those initial findings. Be strong. The chances are EXTREMELY good that good results will result!

Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled Scared to death - help

Posts.Content: My Zytiga journey is *OVER*. EXTREME muscle cramping (even while doing nothing, but especially while sleeping) sent me into "10" pain some of the time, and "9" pain the rest. There was NO position of comfort that would even get the pain to "3" or so. Funny it did not affect my lower body, but my upper....UN-F-ing Believeable. I started taking Zytiga in early October, and had seemingly NO side-effects whatsoever. Around mid-October I started getting minor aches in the back/neck, but attributed them to "overdoing" some physical activity. The aches came more frequently and intensely, and the latest bout a few days ago was immobilizing without beaucoup drugs. I had deliberately NOT done any physical work that might "set off" the cramping a few days prior to Monday the 5th, because I had to drive my spouse to the airport early in the morning, before sunup (she can't drive in the dark). Sunday I was having doubts, as I had periods of INTENSE back pain, but also periods of relative calm. Monday I duly drove (hurting, but not too badly) her, and got some shopping done, but was hurting badly later. THEN, on Tuesday I had *THE WORST DAY OF MY LIFE* when agony was my constant companion. I mean SCREAMING OUT LOUD agony. Luckily, a phone call to my onc got me a prescription for "Soma" a strong muscle-relaxant, and the order to stop taking the Zytiga. I had a small window of "medium" pain, so drove myself to the pharmacy. I am assuming I have a build-up of Zytiga in my system that will take a while to purge, but at least with the Soma and Percoset my pains are now minimal again. But I am in a drugged haze, having difficulty typing (probably 10-15 errors per line I have to go back and correct). My reactions to Zytiga might be extreme, but there is NO WAY I can continue. I see my onc tomorrow, so we will re-stratigize then. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Posts.Title: My Zytiga Journey...OVER!

Posts.Content: If you remember, a supposed 6-month Eligard shot given to me in May of 2006 "burned out" prematurely (long before my scheduled November shot). When I contacted the manufacturers of Eligard, they gave me a factory-fresh 6-month dosage to be administered last November. The 6-month Eligard shot I got last November did the trick--six months later the testosterone was at castration level and my PSA was less than .1 (considered "undetectable"). In May I got another 6-month shot. I got tested for PSA and testosterone in July--perfect scores. So I got "lazy" with the continued success and stopped having frequent tests. Now it is November again, time for my next 6-month shot, and I got tested again just two weeks ago. PSA was up to .14 (low but detectable), and testosterone was 340 (near normal for a male adult). I was SHOCKED! Two out of three Eligard shots have failed. There are other leuprolides out there (Lupron, et. al) and I will try them instead when I resume hormone treatment. (I had agreed with my doctors to go off hormones this November anyway to see how my body and/or cancer responds--will see again in three months whether to go back to hormone treatment). ;-(

Posts.Title: Eligard is Failing Me

Posts.Content: After the failure of my Eligard shot, I wrote to QLT, maker of Eligard, and gave them my numbers and stats and requested a free re-try. That was granted!! They overnighted a fresh batch of 6-mo Eligard to my urologist and I was given the shot. So as of yesterday, I have Eligard in my system again. We will monitor the PSA and testosterone levels each month to try to track the numbers. My first shot back in May may have been a 1-month or 3-month dosage of Eligard by mistake, or....? At any rate, the Eligard manufacturer sent a fresh 6-mo shot and I now will see how THAT works! In the meantime, I went on Casodex 50mg tablets daily, and my most recent PSA was "imperceptible" once again (down from .4 at the beginning of November). At least I know that if the Eligard truly does not work on my particular body, that SOMETHING will.

Posts.Title: Eligard is Failing Me

Posts.Content: I posted here because I thought that his Forum might be a good place to "advertize" that the Eligard did not work and find out if others on the Forum had any similar experience. I know I am an anomaly so far. If someone else out there had the same experience, maybe "our" batch of Eligard was defective or mislabeled, etc. My Urologist is one of the best in San Diego, and I trust his source of Eligard, but the more people "concerned", the more we might get to the bottom of the problem, and faster. I have a letter into the CEO of the company making Eligard, etc. so someone should be concerned that their product is not working. Eligard has been EXTREMELY effective in all other instances so...? My particular prostate tumor was extremely aggressive (Gleason 9+) and fast-moving, unlike most people's that typically move slowly. If I had gotten diagnosed even six months earlier I probably would not have suffered metastasis, so I urge ANYONE with suspicions to get the unpleasant biopsies. My personal opinion is that time is never more "of the essence" than in cancer diagnosis, and "wait and watch" means being a passive spectator in your own slow death.

I know I am an anomaly so far. If someone else out there had the same experience, maybe "our" batch of Eligard was defective or mislabeled, etc. My Urologist is one of the best in San Diego, and I trust his source of Eligard, but the more people "concerned", the more we might get to the bottom of the problem, and faster. I have a letter into the CEO of the company making Eligard, etc. so someone should be concerned that their product is not working. Eligard has been EXTREMELY effective in all other instances so...? My particular prostate tumor was extremely aggressive (Gleason 9+) and fast-moving, unlike most people's that typically move slowly. If I had gotten diagnosed even six months earlier I probably would not have suffered metastasis, so I urge ANYONE with suspicions to get the unpleasant biopsies. My personal opinion is that time is never more "of the essence" than in cancer diagnosis, and "wait and watch" means being a passive spectator in your own slow death.
Posts.Title: Eligard is Failing Me

Posts.Content: I don't even HAVE a prostate anymore--BIG, aggressive tumor yanked out too late, and now metastasis. I gotta supress testosterone so my cancer has nothing to feed upon. I chose the hormone therapy drug "Eligard" that turns off testosterone production. I got a "6 month" Eligard shot at the end of May and in June, a month after my Eligard shot, my PSA came back "imperceptible" and although I did not have a testosterone level test, my libido was DEFINITELY repressed to zero (What *IS* that thing between my legs, and why do I need it??). Then in early October (4 months from injection) I noticed a return of libido, and sure enough, I tested at 350 ng/ml testosterone (full "normal" testosterone levels for a man my age--59), and my PSA was up to .4 WHAT HAPPENED? According to available literature and my urologist/oncologist's experience, testosterone levels should stay supressed much longer than six months with a "six month" shot of Eligard. Either there is still Eligard in my system and my body is somehow rejecting or ignoring it, or it's not there at all and has been somehow metabolized (or incorrectly marked as to dosage in the first place). Am I unique, or is there something else going on? I have heard of a "placebo" Lupron scandal a few years back involving diluting or "cutting" the drug to make someone a profit. Forum Feedback?? Makers of Eligard, are you listening?
Posts.Title: Eligard is Failing Me

Posts.Content: After the failure of my Eligard shot, I wrote to QLT, maker of Eligard, and gave them my numbers and stats and requested a free re-try. That was granted!! They overnighted a fresh batch of 6-mo Eligard to my urologist and I was given the shot. So as of yesterday, I have Eligard in my system again. We will monitor the PSA and testosterone levels each month to try to track the numbers. My first shot back in May may have been a 1-month or 3-month dosage of Eligard by mistake, or....? At any rate, the Eligard manufacturer sent a fresh 6-mo shot and I now will see how THAT works! In the meantime, I went on Casodex 50mg tablets daily, and my most recent PSA was "imperceptible" once again (down from .4 at the beginning of November). At least I know that if the Eligard truly does not work on my particular body, that SOMETHING will.

Posts.Title: Preemptive Prostate Removal?

Posts.Content: I am on Taxotere as we speak. My initial batch was to be six infusions, each three weeks apart. At the time of the first infusion, it was LIKELY that I would be given additional infusions beyond six. Each time my PSA has been checked, it has lowered, though the last one lowered only a slight bit, so I may be approaching "nadir" of effectiveness. I am slated for a total of ten. I am mostly through #7. I intend to keep with it as long as my PSA is dropping or "level", but if it starts to rise I will quit the debilitating chemo regimen and go on to something else. (Those "something elses" will be more desperate and "Hail Mary" solutions---trials of promising treatments). Compared to when I first started taking Taxotere, I am MUCH BETTER off pain-wise (as a result of zapping the cancer causing the bone pain). For some people, PSA measurements do not tell the story. For me they do. Has your onc suggested any way to tell if the chemo regimen has reduced your cancer??

Posts.Content: > I just am fed up with the debilitating chemo, and if there is no real difference between continuing and stopping, then I would like to stop.< Boy, I hear you LOUD AND CLEAR there!! But my Gleason 9 pc is such an aggressive, sly devil, that I would be reluctant to let off once I have "stepped on its neck". With each previous "treatment" (of various sorts) when I thought I had a "respite", my pc went wild and I was in "catch-up" mode once again. So I will "gut it out" *IF*, as you say, there are still benefits to continuing. But I am VERY EAGER to stop the chemo and give my besieged body a bit of rest from chemical assault.

Posts.Title: Newbie with question re extending chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I might try this: Pack it with a COUPLE of ice cubes in a baggie---declare the baggie when going through security so there are no ugly surprises, and then "re-pack" on the plane with the ice with which they serve drinks. That should keep it reasonably cool. You might call TSA ahead of time to make sure that the ice/water isn't considered a threat---I think if you keep it under 3 oz it's OK. There *MUST* be reasonable air travel rules in place for medicines that need to be kept refrigerated. Once you are in steamy Manila... you are on your own!!

Posts.Title: Friend Died From Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Yes, my catheter was merely a nuisance. As you might know, there is a bulb (deflated as it goes up and in) that is expanded once inside the bladder, and it will NOT come out without a gorilla tug on it. But...you want to make sure that the tube does not hook on anything (like a passing subway train, etc!**) and yank it out, because its REALLY gonna hurt and take out your whole urinary system, too. When you need it taken out, the bulb will be deflated and it slips out rather easily. In the meantime, remember you have a hard-rubber hose where you sit--Bicycling is OUT, as well as bumpy roads in a car. Incidentally, driving is NOT recommended until the catheter comes back out--too chancy you might "step on the brakes" suddenly and include the hose with it. ;-( For me, my second time (for some additional surgery) was actually a blessing---I was getting up to pee every 45 minutes around the clock---with the catheter I slept through the night, and merely emptied the bag in the morning. Because there is naturally some inner irritation to the bladder, you might be prescribed "vesicare" or some other such drug that calms the bladder. Some bladder spasming might occur, too. Usually that is at the end of the catheter period when the bladder is as much saying--"I'm OK now, GET THIS THING OUTTA ME!" Although there is nothing pleasant about having a catheter in, it is only a minor and short-term annoyance. Good Luck! **PS--I am sure that ANYONE who has experienced a catheter will instantly shudder and wince at the thought here!!

Posts.Title: Xtandi, and Samarium 153

Posts.Content: Improvement Possible? Why Yes, but I would be cautiously optimistic. I, too, have stage 4 with bone mets, and am currently on Taxotere (it's working to drive out the cancer), but have been on Provenge, radiation, surgery, and hormone-deprivation regimens, too, and am getting Zometa (bone-building stuff). My pc is very aggressive (Gleason 9+). I "went refractory" after four years of Hormone Therapy and have had a whole series of "scares" and therapies over the last year. The Sloan-Kettering institute, the nation's top cancer research center, says that no clinical, controlled trials have substantiated the claims of Dr. Sartori (the main proponent of Cesium Chloride treatments), and that Cesium Chloride is highly toxic to human bodies. http://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/herb/cesium-chloride I can only wish you "best of luck" and hope that obstinancy and/or resistance to standard treatments don't cloud your vision that this pc stuff is no casual thing to toss off lightly. It's DEADLY.

Posts.Title: "Alarming" Chemo Discovery

Posts.Content: >It's the headline writers in the popular media who decided to sensationalize the story, not the scientists who did the work.< Apparently so. As I said, I would have thought that such a revelation would ROCK the cancer treatment world and have oncologists scrambling. My onc said that there are SO MANY mechanisms at work in the cell (maybe a hundred or more) and their interactions are poorly understood (ONE reason why cancer "cures" are so elusive). So this seemingly sensational "find" was really "no big deal".

Posts.Title: "Alarming" Chemo Discovery

Posts.Content: newporter: >Sequoiaranger, you started Taxotere in April. Is everything OK? Perhaps you should ask your doctor about BIND-014 or something similar just in case Taxotere stops working for you? Just a thought and best of luck to you. Your courage and perseverance are great inspirations to me. < Everything is OK, so far. Had my 7th infusion two days ago, and am entering the week-long "Neulasta Netherworld" of flu-like symptoms and general malaise. My "plan" is for three more (total, 10) infusions. My PSA had been dropping precipitously each infusion until the last one, where rather than a 30% drop or so, it was only 6%. Might just be a "bauble", might indicate the point of diminishing return. I have inquired into a "local" BIND-014 trial. They have openings RIGHT NOW, but I am temporarily ineligible (being under treatment). So I am sticking to my current regimen for at least one more PSA test. The BIND-014 system does use Taxotere, but of course rather than "broadcast" the drug throughout the body, cancer cells are targeted. I fully realize that cancer, especially at Gleason 9, is a CHRONIC disease, but I am getting really tired of being under a constant state of "emergency" trying to stifle expansive growth. Comparatively, it was so nice to be merely on Lupron when it was keeping my monster quiescent.

Posts.Title: "Alarming" Chemo Discovery

Posts.Content: Searching for the source of the story on the mystery protein (yahoonews isn't exactly a proper medical journal), I found it difficult to find more info. My internet research lead to an ANTI-medical-establishment website that wanted me to pay for more info. Hmmm. Now the "reliability" of the chemo revelation is suspect, IMHO. I would *THINK* that if the discovered protein and its mechanism were as described, it would be WORLD NEWS of the highest importance, "overturning" the long-established benefits of traditional chemotherapy. OK--found a little more: http://www.nature.com/nm/journal/vao...s/nm.2890.html
